countermeasure.name: Implement static code analysis in development lifecycle
countermeasure.desc: Integrate static code analysis tools into your software development lifecycle to proactively identify and remediate security flaws in the source code. Configure these tools to automatically scan code commits in your version control system (e.g., GitHub, Bitbucket) as part of your CI/CD pipeline. This practice helps in early detection of vulnerabilities, such as SQL injection or cross-site scripting, thus preventing potential exploits in production environments. Regularly update the rulesets of these tools to cover the latest security threats.

countermeasure.name: Reduce container attack surface by stripping unneeded capabilities
countermeasure.desc: Minimize security risks by configuring containers to operate with the least privileges necessary, stripping unneeded capabilities that could be exploited in an attack. Use Linux capabilities to manage and restrict the rights granted to containers. Tools such as Docker can specify dropped capabilities in container runtime configurations. Regularly audit and update the list of capabilities to ensure it aligns with the evolving security landscape and the specific needs of your applications.

countermeasure.name: Restrict container image permissions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that container images are configured with the minimal set of permissions necessary for their operation. Use the principle of least privilege when setting up roles and permissions in your container orchestration platform, such as Amazon ECS. Define specific IAM roles for each container or service that grant only the required permissions for tasks they need to perform. Regular audits and reviews of permissions should be conducted to eliminate excess privileges that could be exploited by attackers.

countermeasure.name: Restrict containers from running with privileged status
countermeasure.desc: To enhance security within your Amazon VPC, ensure that containers deployed on Amazon ECS do not run with privileged status. This practice prevents containers from accessing critical host resources, mitigating the risk of system-level compromises. Implement this control by setting the privileged parameter to false in your container definitions within the ECS task configuration. Regularly review and audit your ECS task definitions to enforce and verify this security setting, ensuring compliance across your deployments.

countermeasure.name: Run container processes as non-root users
countermeasure.desc: To limit the potential impact of a security breach, configure your container processes to execute as non-root users. This reduces the risk of privileged escalations. In the Dockerfile, use the USER instruction to specify a non-root user before running any commands. Ensure that this user has the appropriate permissions required to operate the application, and nothing more. Regularly review and tighten these permissions as part of your container security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Scan application dependencies for security vulnerabilities
countermeasure.desc: Regularly scan all application dependencies for known security issues to prevent exploitation. Use tools such as OWASP Dependency-Check or Snyk within your development pipeline to automate the scanning process. Configure these tools to trigger scans on code commits or during build processes. Update dependencies frequently based on the scan reports to mitigate any identified vulnerabilities, ensuring that your applications remain secure against known threats.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource exhaustion occurs when a system's resources, such as CPU, memory, or network bandwidth, are overwhelmed, typically by malicious intent. This can happen when excessive demands are placed on these resources, making the system slow or unresponsive.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers might employ scripts or bots to create a large number of tasks or services within Amazon ECS, or they might manipulate application processes to consume more resources than allocated. External attackers or malicious insiders could both exploit this vulnerability.

Impacts

Resource exhaustion can lead to denial of service (DoS), decreased application performance, and potential system crashes. In a cloud environment like ECS, it could also lead to increased costs due to resource scaling to meet the illegitimate demand.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could deploy a container in ECS that purposely consumes an excessive amount of CPU and memory resources, affecting other containers running on the same cluster. Alternatively, an attacker could trigger a flood of requests that overwhelm the application, causing legitimate requests to time out or fail.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege escalation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Privilege escalation occurs when an entity gains elevated access to resources that are normally protected from an application or user. This can happen when a user or process gains rights or permissions beyond those originally granted, potentially leading to unauthorized system access or control.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attack vectors could include exploiting vulnerabilities in software, misconfigurations in security settings, or compromising lower-level user accounts that interact with Amazon ECS. This could be orchestrated by external attackers or malicious insiders.

Impacts

The impacts of privilege escalation are severe and can include unauthorized data access, data manipulation, and persistent access to the system, which might compromise the entire ECS cluster. It may also lead to further attacks on connected systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker might exploit a vulnerability in an application running in a container, allowing them to execute commands as a root user. Alternatively, an attacker could use a stolen set of credentials to modify ECS task definitions to run arbitrary commands, thereby escalating privileges within the cluster.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Image integrity and confidentiality
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat involves unauthorized alterations to container images or exposure of their contents. It can occur when images are not adequately secured, allowing attackers to inject malicious code or access sensitive data embedded in the images.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attack vectors include compromised credentials, insecure image repositories, and man-in-the-middle attacks during image transfer. Both external attackers and malicious insiders with access to image repositories can pose a threat.

Impacts

Compromised image integrity can lead to the deployment of malicious containers, resulting in unauthorized actions within the infrastructure. Breaches of confidentiality can expose sensitive data, intellectual property, or regulatory-controlled information.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could intercept an image during transfer and inject malicious code, which is then executed within the ECS environment when the container is run. Alternatively, an attacker with access to the image repository might alter an image to create a backdoor in applications deployed from it.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure container images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure container images contain vulnerabilities or misconfigurations that can be exploited by attackers. These issues may arise from outdated software, inadequate security settings, or embedded malicious code.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who might exploit known vulnerabilities or insiders who could introduce vulnerabilities intentionally. Common attack vectors are compromised image repositories or using unverified images from public registries.

Impacts

Using insecure images can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and persistent malware within the cloud infrastructure. The security and operational integrity of the entire ECS environment can be compromised.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could push a compromised image to a public repository that is then used unknowingly in production environments, leading to system compromise. Alternatively, an outdated image could be deployed, containing vulnerabilities that attackers exploit to gain control over the container and associated services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

threat.name: Code vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code vulnerabilities refer to flaws in software that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access or cause harm. These vulnerabilities can exist in the application code itself or within the libraries and dependencies the application uses.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Potential exploiters include external attackers using known vulnerabilities and internal users inadvertently introducing vulnerable code. Common vectors include injection attacks, cross-site scripting (XSS), and outdated libraries with known exploits.

Impacts

Exploiting these vulnerabilities can lead to data breaches, unauthorized access, and other security incidents. The impact is often system compromise or data exposure, potentially leading to significant operational and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker might use a SQL injection vulnerability in application code running in an ECS container to extract sensitive database information. Alternatively, exploiting a known vulnerability in a third-party library could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code within the container.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Enable at-rest encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Configure encryption for data at rest in AWS EMR using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) or other suitable encryption methods to protect sensitive information. This involves setting up encryption for all storage volumes and data stores used by EMR clusters to ensure that data remains secure and inaccessible to unauthorized users, even if the underlying storage media is compromised.

  1. Enable EBS Volume Encryption: Configure EMR to use encrypted EBS volumes for all instances. Use AWS KMS to manage encryption keys.
  2. Encrypt S3 Data: Ensure that data stored in S3 buckets, used by EMR for input, output, and logging, is encrypted. Utilize server-side encryption with AWS KMS-managed keys (SSE-KMS) or customer-provided keys (SSE-C).
  3. Local Disk Encryption: Configure local disk encryption on cluster nodes using AWS KMS keys to protect temporary data stored during processing.
  4. HDFS Encryption: Enable HDFS encryption to secure data stored in the Hadoop Distributed File System on EMR clusters.
  5. Regularly Rotate Keys: Implement a key rotation policy to regularly update encryption keys, reducing the risk of key compromise.

reference.name: Best Practices for Securing Amazon EMR

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Harden custom AMIs for EMR clusters
countermeasure.desc:
Apply CIS (Center for Internet Security) controls and other hardening measures to custom Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) used with AWS EMR clusters. Regularly update and maintain these AMIs to ensure they remain secure and compliant with the latest security standards. This involves configuring security settings, removing unnecessary services, and applying security patches to minimize vulnerabilities.

  1. Apply CIS Benchmarks: Use the CIS Amazon Linux Benchmark or other relevant CIS benchmarks as guidelines to harden custom AMIs. Implement recommended configurations to enhance security, such as disabling unnecessary services, securing user accounts, and configuring network settings.
  2. Remove Unnecessary Services: Disable or remove any services and applications that are not required for the EMR clusters operation to reduce the attack surface.
  3. Enable Security Features: Ensure that security features such as SELinux, firewall configurations, and intrusion detection systems are enabled and properly configured.
  4. Regular Updates and Patching: Frequently update the AMIs with the latest security patches and updates to address vulnerabilities. Automate this process to ensure consistency and regularity.
  5. Automate AMI Hardening: Use automation tools such as AWS Systems Manager, AWS Lambda, or custom scripts to apply hardening measures consistently across all custom AMIs.
  6. Document and Review: Maintain thorough documentation of the hardening process and configurations applied to custom AMIs. Regularly review and update these measures to address new security threats and best practices.

reference.name: Best Practices for Securing Amazon EMR

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation

countermeasure.name: Implement Kerberos authentication for EMR clusters
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Kerberos authentication to securely verify the identity of users accessing AWS EMR clusters. Kerberos is a network authentication protocol that uses secret-key cryptography to provide strong authentication for client-server applications. Configuring Kerberos in your EMR environment ensures that only authenticated and authorized users can access the cluster resources, enhancing the security of your data and operations.

  1. Set Up a Kerberos Realm: Configure a Kerberos realm that will manage the authentication of users and services. This involves setting up a Key Distribution Center (KDC) which includes the Authentication Server (AS) and Ticket Granting Server (TGS).
  2. Integrate with Active Directory (Optional): For organizations using Active Directory, establish a cross-realm trust between the Kerberos realm and Active Directory to allow seamless authentication for users.
  3. Configure Kerberos on EMR: Enable Kerberos for your EMR clusters during the cluster creation process. Use the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or CloudFormation templates to specify Kerberos-related configuration details.
  4. Manage Kerberos Principals: Create and manage Kerberos principals (users and services) required for authentication. Ensure that each principal has a unique key.
  5. Secure Key Storage: Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) or other secure methods to store and manage the keys used for Kerberos authentication.
  6. Monitor and Audit Authentication Logs: Implement logging and monitoring for Kerberos authentication events. Use AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch to capture and analyze authentication logs for any suspicious activities.

reference.name: Use Kerberos for authentication with Amazon EMR

standard.ref: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Isolate EMR clusters in private subnets
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that EMR clusters are placed in private subnets with no direct access to the internet. Use NAT gateways or VPC endpoints to facilitate necessary communications. This enhances the security of your EMR clusters by minimizing exposure to external threats and ensuring that only authorized internal traffic can reach your EMR resources.

  1. Place Clusters in Private Subnets: When creating an EMR cluster, configure the network settings to place all instances in private subnets within your VPC. This ensures that they are not directly accessible from the internet.
  2. Use NAT Gateways: Configure NAT gateways to allow instances in the private subnets to initiate outbound connections to the internet for updates and other necessary communications while preventing inbound traffic from the internet.
  3. VPC Endpoints: Utilize VPC endpoints to securely connect to AWS services such as Amazon S3 and DynamoDB without traversing the public internet. This ensures that data transfers between your EMR clusters and AWS services remain within the AWS network.
  4. Security Groups and NACLs: Implement security groups and network ACLs to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from your EMR clusters. Restrict access to only trusted IP ranges and necessary ports.
  5. Regular Audits: Conduct regular audits of your VPC configuration, security group rules, and NACLs to ensure compliance with best practices and security policies.

reference.name: Configure networking

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit EMR configurations and practices
countermeasure.desc:
Perform regular audits of AWS EMR configurations and operational practices to ensure compliance with security standards and best practices. This involves systematically reviewing security settings, access controls, and cluster configurations to identify and remediate potential vulnerabilities. Use both automated tools and manual assessments to conduct comprehensive audits. Regular audits help maintain a strong security posture and ensure adherence to regulatory and organizational policies.

  1. Schedule Regular Audits: Establish a routine audit schedule to review EMR configurations and practices periodically (e.g., quarterly).
  2. Automate Configuration Checks: Use AWS Config, AWS CloudTrail, and AWS Security Hub to automate the detection of configuration changes and compliance checks.
  3. Manual Assessments: Complement automated checks with manual reviews to catch issues that automated tools may miss.
  4. Review Security Groups and IAM Policies: Ensure that security groups and IAM policies are configured according to the principle of least privilege and do not expose unnecessary access.
  5. Verify Data Encryption: Check that data at rest and in transit is encrypted using appropriate encryption standards.
  6. Document Findings and Remediations: Maintain thorough documentation of audit findings, actions taken to remediate issues, and any changes made to security policies.

reference.name: Best Practices for Securing Amazon EMR

countermeasure.name: Secure and audit bootstrap actions
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that bootstrap actions in AWS EMR are securely written, stored, and executed. Monitor and audit these actions to maintain compliance with security best practices. Bootstrap actions are scripts that run on cluster nodes at startup, and securing them is crucial to prevent the introduction of vulnerabilities or unauthorized access.

  1. Write Secure Scripts: Ensure that all bootstrap scripts are securely coded, following best practices for scripting and handling sensitive information. Avoid hardcoding credentials or sensitive data within the scripts.
  2. Secure Storage: Store bootstrap scripts in secure locations such as private S3 buckets with strict access controls. Use bucket policies and IAM roles to restrict access to authorized users only.
  3. Encrypt Scripts: Use server-side encryption (SSE) with AWS KMS for S3 buckets storing bootstrap scripts to protect them from unauthorized access.
  4. Execution Security: Configure EMR clusters to execute bootstrap actions in a secure manner. Ensure that scripts are pulled from secure locations using HTTPS to prevent man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks.
  5. Monitoring and Auditing: Implement logging and monitoring for bootstrap actions using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch. Regularly review logs to detect any unauthorized or suspicious activities related to script execution.
  6. Regular Reviews: Conduct periodic audits of all bootstrap actions to ensure they comply with security best practices and organizational policies. Update and refine scripts as necessary to address new security threats.

reference.name: Best Practices for Securing Amazon EMR

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposure of data at rest refers to the risk of sensitive data being accessed by unauthorized users while stored on disk in AWS EMR. This can occur due to lack of encryption, improper access controls, or misconfigurations, potentially leading to data breaches and loss of sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted storage volumes.
    • Misconfigured access permissions on storage resources.
    • Unauthorized access to backup and snapshot data.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to confidentiality breaches.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for data protection.
  • Operational Disruption: Data tampering or deletion affecting the integrity and availability of EMR operations.
  • Financial and Reputational Damage: Significant financial losses and reputational harm due to data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage Volumes: An administrator fails to enable encryption for EBS volumes used by EMR clusters. An attacker gains physical access to the storage media or exploits vulnerabilities to read the unencrypted data.
  2. Misconfigured Access Permissions: Storage resources have overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access and extract sensitive data stored within EMR clusters.
  3. Snapshot Exposure: Snapshots of EMR cluster data are created without proper encryption or access restrictions. An attacker gains access to these snapshots and extracts sensitive information.

By enabling encryption for data at rest and implementing strict access controls, these risks can be mitigated.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Unauthorized access to EMR clusters
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to EMR clusters involves individuals gaining access to the clusters without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, misconfigurations, or exploitation of vulnerabilities, leading to potential data breaches, operational disruptions, and misuse of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised credentials.
    • Misconfigured IAM roles or policies.
    • Exploitation of network vulnerabilities.
    • Inadequate security group settings.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access can lead to the exposure of sensitive data processed or stored in the EMR clusters.
  • Operational Disruptions: Malicious activities can disrupt EMR operations, leading to downtime and loss of productivity.
  • Resource Misuse: Unauthorized users may exploit EMR resources for illicit activities, increasing operational costs.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized access can lead to non-compliance with data protection regulations, resulting in legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker gains access to EMR clusters using stolen or weak credentials. They exploit this access to extract sensitive data or disrupt cluster operations.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Policies: IAM policies with overly permissive settings allow unauthorized users to perform actions beyond their intended scope, leading to data breaches and unauthorized modifications.
  3. Inadequate Security Group Settings: Security groups with open inbound rules allow an attacker to gain network access to EMR clusters, from where they can execute commands and access data.
  4. Exploitation of Network Vulnerabilities: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the network configuration, such as improperly configured VPCs or lack of encryption, to gain unauthorized access to EMR clusters.

By implementing strong access controls, regularly auditing IAM policies, and securing network configurations, these risks can be mitigated.

threat.name: Public exposure of EMR clusters
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Public exposure of EMR clusters occurs when these clusters are accessible from the internet, increasing the risk of unauthorized access and attacks. This typically happens due to misconfigurations in network settings, such as placing clusters in public subnets or improper security group settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Publicly accessible subnets.
    • Security groups with open inbound rules.
    • Misconfigured VPC settings allowing unrestricted access.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: External attackers can exploit publicly accessible clusters, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive information stored or processed by the EMR cluster.
  • Service Disruption: Potential denial-of-service (DoS) attacks or malicious activities disrupting cluster operations.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to comply with data protection regulations, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Security Groups: An EMR cluster is placed in a public subnet with security groups that allow inbound traffic from any IP address. An attacker scans for open ports and gains access to the cluster, extracting sensitive data.
  2. Misconfigured VPC: A misconfigured VPC setup exposes the EMR cluster to the internet, allowing an attacker to launch a brute force attack on cluster nodes, eventually gaining access and causing data loss.
  3. Public Subnet Placement: An EMR cluster is unintentionally deployed in a public subnet. An external attacker discovers the cluster through internet scanning tools and exploits vulnerabilities to infiltrate the system.

By placing EMR clusters in private subnets and carefully configuring security groups, these risks can be significantly reduced.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Insecure custom AMIs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure Custom Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) pose a significant threat to AWS EMR clusters by potentially introducing vulnerabilities through misconfigurations, outdated software, or inclusion of malicious code. Custom AMIs are often used to tailor the EMR environment to specific needs, but without proper security measures, they can become a vector for attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inclusion of vulnerable or malicious software in AMIs.
    • Misconfigurations leading to security gaps.
    • Failure to apply security patches and updates.
    • Improperly secured storage and distribution of AMIs.

Impacts

  • Security Breaches: Vulnerabilities in custom AMIs can be exploited to gain unauthorized access or execute malicious activities.
  • Data Compromise: Sensitive data within the EMR clusters can be exposed or tampered with.
  • Operational Disruptions: Compromised AMIs can lead to unstable or disrupted EMR operations.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Using insecure AMIs can result in failing to meet regulatory and compliance requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Inclusion of Malicious Code: A custom AMI is created with embedded malicious code. When used in an EMR cluster, this code executes, providing an attacker with backdoor access to the system.
  2. Outdated Software: A custom AMI includes outdated software with known vulnerabilities. An attacker exploits these vulnerabilities to gain control of the EMR cluster and access sensitive data.
  3. Misconfigured Services: Services within the custom AMI are misconfigured, leaving ports open or using weak authentication methods. An attacker scans for these vulnerabilities and gains unauthorized access.

By ensuring custom AMIs are properly hardened, regularly updated, and securely stored, these risks can be mitigated.

threat.name: Lack of regular audits
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposure of data at rest refers to the risk of sensitive data being accessed by unauthorized users while stored on disk in AWS EMR. This can occur due to lack of encryption, improper access controls, or misconfigurations, potentially leading to data breaches and loss of sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted storage volumes.
    • Misconfigured access permissions on storage resources.
    • Unauthorized access to backup and snapshot data.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to confidentiality breaches.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for data protection.
  • Operational Disruption: Data tampering or deletion affecting the integrity and availability of EMR operations.
  • Financial and Reputational Damage: Significant financial losses and reputational harm due to data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage Volumes: An administrator fails to enable encryption for EBS volumes used by EMR clusters. An attacker gains physical access to the storage media or exploits vulnerabilities to read the unencrypted data.
  2. Misconfigured Access Permissions: Storage resources have overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access and extract sensitive data stored within EMR clusters.
  3. Snapshot Exposure: Snapshots of EMR cluster data are created without proper encryption or access restrictions. An attacker gains access to these snapshots and extracts sensitive information.

By enabling encryption for data at rest and implementing strict access controls, these risks can be mitigated.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure bootstrap actions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure bootstrap actions in AWS EMR involve running scripts or commands during cluster launch that may introduce vulnerabilities if not properly secured. These scripts can configure clusters but can also expose the system to risks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure script storage (e.g., public S3 buckets).
    • Embedded credentials in scripts.
    • Improper permissions on scripts.
    • MITM attacks during script retrieval.

Impacts

  • Security Breaches: Unauthorized access to resources or data.
  • Data Exposure: Sensitive information exposed through scripts.
  • Service Disruption: Cluster instability or failure due to malicious scripts.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of regulatory standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Script Storage: An attacker modifies a publicly accessible script in an S3 bucket, gaining unauthorized access when the cluster is launched.
  2. Embedded Credentials: Hard-coded credentials in a script are extracted by an attacker, leading to unauthorized access to AWS resources.
  3. MITM Attack: An attacker intercepts an insecure HTTP connection to modify a bootstrap script, embedding malicious code.
  4. Improper Permissions: An insider modifies a script with overly permissive permissions, disrupting cluster operations.

By securing storage, encrypting transmission, and managing access controls, these risks can be mitigated.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to configure and invoke EventBridge targets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge targets, apply IAM policies that restrict which users and roles have permissions to configure and invoke targets. These policies ensure that only authorized entities can trigger actions on the EventBridge targets, preventing unauthorized operations and maintaining the integrity of the event-driven workflow.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the specific actions (e.g., PutRule, PutTargets, InvokeFunction) that need to be restricted and identify the users and roles that require these permissions.
  2. Create IAM Policies: Develop IAM policies that explicitly define which users and roles are allowed to configure and invoke EventBridge targets. Use least privilege principles to grant only the necessary permissions required for their roles.
  3. Attach Policies to Users and Roles: Attach the IAM policies to the appropriate users, groups, or roles in AWS IAM to enforce the defined access restrictions.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review IAM policies to ensure they are up-to-date with current organizational requirements and remove any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Monitor Access and Usage: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor who is configuring and invoking EventBridge targets. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or actions.

reference.name: Using identity-based policies (IAM policies) for Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging for all event activities in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility and security monitoring in AWS EventBridge, enable detailed logging for all event activities. Use Amazon CloudWatch Logs and AWS CloudTrail to capture and monitor event-related actions, including event publishing, rule evaluation, and target invocation. Detailed logging helps detect unauthorized access, misconfigurations, and anomalies, allowing timely incident response and improving overall security posture.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable CloudTrail for EventBridge: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled for your AWS account to log all EventBridge API calls. Configure CloudTrail to log both management events and data events for comprehensive coverage.
  2. Set Up CloudWatch Logs: Create log groups and set up CloudWatch Logs to capture and store logs generated by EventBridge activities. Ensure logs are retained for an appropriate period based on your organization's retention policy.
  3. Monitor Logs and Set Alerts: Use CloudWatch metrics and alarms to monitor EventBridge activity logs for any unauthorized or suspicious actions. Configure alerts to notify security teams of any anomalies or potential security incidents.
  4. Regularly Review Logs: Schedule regular reviews of CloudWatch Logs and CloudTrail logs to identify trends, detect potential threats, and ensure compliance with security policies.
  5. Audit Log Configurations: Periodically audit logging configurations to ensure that all EventBridge activities are being logged correctly and that logging mechanisms are operating as intended.

reference.name: Logging Amazon EventBridge API calls using AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in event payloads before sending to AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To protect sensitive data transmitted through AWS EventBridge, ensure that all sensitive information included in event payloads is encrypted before being sent. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encrypting data to safeguard against unauthorized access and potential data breaches. Encrypting sensitive data ensures its confidentiality and integrity, even if it is intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data: Determine which data fields in event payloads contain sensitive information that requires encryption, such as personally identifiable information (PII) or financial details.
  2. Use AWS KMS for Encryption: Utilize AWS KMS to encrypt sensitive data within the payloads. Integrate AWS KMS encryption into your application's event generation process to automatically encrypt sensitive data before sending it to EventBridge.
  3. Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure that encrypted payloads are transmitted over secure channels, such as HTTPS, to add another layer of protection during data transit.
  4. Regularly Review Encryption Policies: Periodically review and update encryption practices and KMS key policies to align with organizational security standards and compliance requirements.
  5. Audit Encrypted Payloads: Regularly audit event payloads to verify that sensitive data is properly encrypted and that no plaintext sensitive information is sent through EventBridge.

reference.name: Data protection in Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped

SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and validate event rule configurations in AWS EventBridge
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain secure and efficient event routing in AWS EventBridge, regularly review and validate the configuration of event rules. Ensure that each rule routes events only to authorized targets and that the configurations are not overly permissive. This practice adheres to the principle of least privilege, minimizing the risk of unauthorized actions or data exposure.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Schedule Regular Rule Reviews: Establish a routine schedule for reviewing all EventBridge event rules to ensure they are properly configured and align with security policies.
  2. Validate Target Authorizations: Check that each event rule routes events only to authorized targets, and ensure that no unauthorized targets are included.
  3. Minimize Rule Permissions: Review rule conditions and filters to ensure they are specific and not overly broad or permissive. Adjust configurations to follow the principle of least privilege.
  4. Document and Track Changes: Maintain a log of all rule reviews and any changes made to event rule configurations for auditing purposes.
  5. Automate Validation Checks: Where possible, automate the validation of event rule configurations using AWS Config or custom scripts to identify any non-compliant or overly permissive rules.

reference.name: Creating a rule that runs on a schedule in Amazon EventBridge

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to restrict access to the EventBridge event bus
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EventBridge event buses, implement resource-based policies that restrict access to only authorized AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users. By defining specific permissions within these policies, you can control who can publish or subscribe to events on the event bus, thereby preventing unauthorized access and ensuring that only trusted entities can interact with the event bus.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify Authorized Entities: Determine which AWS accounts, IAM roles, or users require access to the event bus for publishing or subscribing to events.
  2. Create Resource-Based Policies: Develop resource-based policies that explicitly grant the necessary permissions (e.g., PutEvents, DescribeRule, ListTargets) to the identified entities. Specify conditions where appropriate to further refine access.
  3. Attach Policies to the Event Bus: Attach the resource-based policies directly to the event bus to enforce the defined access controls. Ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the resource-based policies to ensure they remain up-to-date with current access requirements and revoke any unnecessary permissions.
  5. Audit Access Logs: Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs to monitor access to the event bus, ensuring compliance with the defined policies and detecting any unauthorized access attempts.

reference.name: Permissions for event buses in Amazon EventBridge

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation of EventBridge targets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized invocation of AWS EventBridge targets occurs when unauthorized users or services trigger actions or access resources through EventBridge, potentially leading to data exposure, service disruption, or unintended operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak permissions to invoke targets without authorization.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to invoke unauthorized actions on targets.
  • Misconfigured Policies: Overly permissive IAM policies allow unintended target invocations.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized actions could expose sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious or unintended invocations can disrupt normal operations.
  • Security Breaches: Compromised targets could be used to further penetrate the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Weak Permissions: An attacker exploits weak IAM policies to invoke a target and access sensitive data.
  2. Misuse of Privileges: An insider with elevated permissions invokes unauthorized actions, causing data leakage or disruption.
  3. Malicious Automation: Bots exploit misconfigurations to repeatedly invoke targets, leading to service degradation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in event payloads
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data in AWS EventBridge event payloads can be exposed if not properly protected, leading to unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intercept unprotected event data or exploit misconfigurations.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to view or extract sensitive data.
  • Misconfigured Rules: Send sensitive data to unauthorized targets.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection laws, leading to fines.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust due to data exposure.
  • Financial Loss: Costs from breach response and legal actions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Data: Attackers intercept unencrypted event payloads containing sensitive data.
  2. Misconfigured Rules: Sensitive data is sent to unauthorized recipients due to misconfigured rules.
  3. Insider Misuse: An employee accesses and misuses sensitive event data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1081 - Credentials in Files

threat.name: Unrestricted event bus access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unrestricted access to an AWS EventBridge event bus can allow unauthorized users or services to publish or subscribe to events. This can lead to unauthorized data exposure, manipulation of event data, or triggering of unintended actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit open access to publish malicious events or intercept sensitive data.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to the event bus to perform unauthorized operations.
  • Misconfigurations: Improperly configured access controls that allow broad or unrestricted access.

Impacts

  • Data Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive events or data.
  • Security Breach: Malicious events may trigger unauthorized actions or compromise system integrity.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended events could disrupt workflows or services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Event Publishing: An attacker publishes malicious events to an open event bus, triggering unauthorized actions.
  2. Data Interception: Insiders with unrestricted access subscribe to events and intercept sensitive data.
  3. Misconfigured Access Controls: Improperly configured access policies allow unintended users to publish or consume events from the event bus.

threat.name: Misconfigured event rules
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured event rules in AWS EventBridge can lead to unintended or unauthorized event routing, exposing sensitive data or triggering unintended actions. This increases the risk of data leaks and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit misconfigurations to redirect events to unauthorized targets.
  • Insiders: Incorrectly configure event rules, leading to unintended data exposure or actions.
  • Automated Bots: Detect and exploit weak configurations to manipulate event flow.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive data could be routed to unauthorized recipients.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended event triggers could disrupt services or workflows.
  • Security Breaches: Malicious actions could be triggered by misrouted events.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker exploits a misconfiguration to redirect events to a malicious endpoint.
  2. Incorrect Rule Configuration: An insider mistakenly configures a rule that sends sensitive data to an unauthorized service.
  3. Service Disruption: Misconfigured rules cause an unexpected series of actions, disrupting normal operations.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring for event activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A lack of logging and monitoring for event activities in AWS EventBridge can prevent the timely detection and response to unauthorized access, misconfigurations, or malicious actions. Without adequate visibility, security incidents may go unnoticed, increasing the risk of data breaches or operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Perform unauthorized activities without detection due to insufficient monitoring.
  • Insiders: Misuse access to EventBridge undetected because of a lack of logs.
  • Malware: Malicious software exploits system weaknesses without triggering alerts.

Impacts

  • Delayed Incident Response: Slow detection of unauthorized access or anomalies increases potential damage.
  • Data Breach: Undetected unauthorized access could lead to exposure of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Unnoticed malicious activities could disrupt services or workflows.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker accesses sensitive event data without being detected due to insufficient logging.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with access misuses EventBridge to send unauthorized events, undetected due to lack of monitoring.
  3. Unnoticed Anomalies: Suspicious patterns or unusual activity go unnoticed, allowing further malicious activities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

component.name: Amazon Kinesis Data Streams
component.desc: AWS service for real-time data streaming.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all actions within AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls. This practice helps detect unauthorized activities and provides a comprehensive audit trail for security reviews. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable CloudTrail:

  • Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • Create a new trail or use an existing trail.
  • Ensure the trail applies to all regions to capture all API activity.

Configure Logging:

  • Specify an S3 bucket for log storage with proper access controls and encryption.
  • Optionally, enable log file validation for added security.

Set Up Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to set up metrics and alarms based on specific API activity patterns.
  • Configure CloudWatch Alarms to alert security personnel when suspicious or unusual API calls are detected.

Review and Analyze Logs:

  • Regularly review CloudTrail logs to identify and investigate unauthorized or suspicious API calls.
  • Use AWS CloudTrail Insights for automated analysis and detection of unusual activity.

reference.name: Logging Amazon Kinesis Data Streams API Calls with AWS CloudTrail

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS KMS-managed keys. This ensures that data is automatically encrypted before being written to the stream and decrypted when read. Follow these steps:

Enable Server-Side Encryption:

  • Navigate to the Kinesis Data Streams console.
  • Select the data stream you want to encrypt.
  • In the stream details, enable server-side encryption.
  • Choose an AWS KMS key to manage the encryption. You can use an AWS-managed key or a customer-managed key (CMK).

Verify Encryption Status:

  • Check the stream details to ensure that SSE is enabled and the correct KMS key is being used.
  • Verify that new data being ingested into the stream is encrypted.

Update IAM Policies:

  • Ensure that IAM roles and policies allow access to the KMS keys used for encryption and decryption.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all access to KMS keys and Kinesis Data Streams.
  • Set up CloudWatch alarms for unusual access patterns or failures in encryption/decryption operations.

reference.name: Data Protection in Amazon Kinesis Data Streams

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted Data at Rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the risk posed by storing data in Kinesis streams without encryption. This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information if someone gains access to the storage backend. Encrypting data at rest ensures that even if physical storage media is compromised, the data remains protected and inaccessible to unauthorized users.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers gaining access to storage media.
  • Malicious insiders with access to storage backend.
  • Unauthorized users exploiting vulnerabilities to access stored data.

Attack Vectors:

  • Physical theft or compromise of storage media.
  • Exploitation of software vulnerabilities that allow access to unencrypted data.
  • Misconfigured access controls allowing unauthorized access to storage resources.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information stored in Kinesis Data Streams, leading to potential data leaks and compliance issues.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Potential alteration of data by unauthorized entities, leading to unreliable or corrupted data.
  • Compliance Violations: Storing unencrypted data may violate industry regulations and standards, leading to legal penalties and reputational damage.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents involving unencrypted data can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Physical Compromise: An external attacker gains physical access to AWS data centers or backup media. Without encryption, the attacker can read sensitive data directly from the storage devices.
  2. Insider Threat: A malicious insider with access to the storage infrastructure retrieves unencrypted data from Kinesis Data Streams and leaks it to external parties, causing a significant data breach.
  3. Exploitation of Misconfigurations: A developer accidentally misconfigures access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access unencrypted data in Kinesis Data Streams. Attackers exploit this vulnerability to extract sensitive information.

By implementing these strategies, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with unencrypted data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, ensuring the protection of sensitive information and compliance with security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Lack of API call monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of API Call Monitoring in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the absence of oversight and tracking of API calls made to the service. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized or malicious activities may go undetected, leading to potential security breaches, data loss, and operational disruptions. Continuous monitoring of API calls is crucial for detecting suspicious activities and ensuring compliance with security policies.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers exploiting unmonitored API calls.
  • Malicious insiders performing unauthorized actions.
  • Compromised accounts used to execute unauthorized API calls.

Attack Vectors:

  • Unauthorized API calls using stolen or compromised credentials.
  • Insiders abusing their access rights to make unauthorized changes.
  • Automated scripts or bots making excessive or unauthorized API requests.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access and actions can lead to data breaches and leakage of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious API calls can disrupt the normal operation of Kinesis Data Streams, leading to downtime and loss of productivity.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of monitoring can result in non-compliance with industry regulations and standards, attracting legal penalties.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents arising from unmonitored API calls can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker gains access to AWS credentials through a phishing attack. Without API call monitoring, the attacker makes unauthorized API calls to Kinesis Data Streams, exfiltrating sensitive data without detection.
  2. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their access rights to perform unauthorized API actions, such as deleting data streams or modifying configurations, causing significant operational disruptions.
  3. Automated Bot Attack: A botnet performs a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack by making excessive API requests to Kinesis Data Streams, overwhelming the service and causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Without monitoring, the attack goes undetected until service disruptions occur.

By implementing these mitigation strategies, organizations can ensure comprehensive monitoring of API calls to AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enhancing security and reducing the risk of unauthorized actions going undetected.

component.name: Amazon MSK
component.desc: AWS managed streaming for Apache Kafka.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

countermeasure.name: Configure broker logs delivery to CloudWatch, S3, or Firehose
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security monitoring of your AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (MSK) cluster, configure your MSK cluster to deliver INFO-level broker logs to destinations such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs, Amazon S3, or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. Implementing this countermeasure involves the following steps:

  1. Enable Broker Logging: Ensure that broker logging is enabled on your MSK cluster. You can specify the log delivery options when you create the cluster or update the configuration of an existing cluster. Refer to the MSK logging documentation for detailed instructions.
  2. Choose Log Destination: Decide where you want the logs to be delivered:
    • Amazon CloudWatch Logs: Select this option for real-time monitoring and alerting capabilities. Configure the log group and define IAM roles and policies for log delivery. For more information, refer to CloudWatch Logs setup guide.
    • Amazon S3: Use S3 to store logs for long-term retention and analysis. Specify the S3 bucket and implement the required IAM policies. Refer to S3 logs setup guide.
    • Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose: Choose Firehose for streamlining log processing and delivery to various destinations. Set up the Firehose delivery stream and apply the necessary IAM policies. See the Firehose setup guide for further details.
  3. Secure IAM Roles and Policies: Ensure that the IAM roles and policies associated with log delivery have the least privilege necessary to perform their functions. Refer to the IAM Security guidelines in the MSK documentation for best practices.
  4. Verify Log Delivery: After configuring log delivery, validate that logs are being correctly sent to the chosen destination. Check the log streams in CloudWatch, the objects in your S3 bucket, or the records in Kinesis Firehose to ensure logs are comprehensive and correctly timestamped.
  5. Monitor and Analyze Logs: Regularly monitor and analyze the INFO-level broker logs to detect any unusual or unauthorized activities. Use AWS security tools like Amazon GuardDuty and AWS Security Hub for advanced threat detection and correlation of log data. Detailed steps can be found in the Monitoring Guide.

For comprehensive security guidelines, please refer to the AWS MSK Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Update security group rules to restrict access
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that your clients have access to the brokers in your AWS MSK cluster, you need to properly configure the security group's rules associated with your MSK cluster. This involves setting inbound and outbound rules that allow traffic between your clients and the brokers while maintaining adherence to AWS security best practices. Below is a step-by-step guide:

  1. Identify the Security Group: First, identify the security group currently associated with your MSK cluster. You can find this information in the AWS Management Console by navigating to the Amazon MSK console.

  2. Access the Security Group Settings: In the MSK console, go to the Cluster details page and then to the Network section. Note the IDs of the security groups used by the brokers.

  3. Edit Inbound Rules: Navigate to the Amazon EC2 console, and then to the Security Groups section. Locate the security groups identified in the previous step, and edit their inbound rules to allow necessary traffic from your clients. Ensure you add rules for the appropriate ports used by MSK (default is TCP port 9092).

    • Click on the Inbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit inbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic from your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092), and the appropriate Source (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  4. Edit Outbound Rules: Ensure the outbound rules permit traffic to the client IPs. Similar to inbound rules, edit the outbound rules for the security group to allow traffic to specified IP ranges and ports.

    • Click on the Outbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit outbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic to your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092 or other custom ports), and the appropriate Destination (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  5. Verify the Configuration: After configuring the security group's rules, ensure that your clients can connect to the brokers without issues. Test the connectivity and ensure that the proper permissions are in place.

  6. Review and Maintain: Regularly review and update the security group rules to align with changing security requirements and best practices. Reference the AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka security documentation for any updates or additional guidelines: AWS MSK Security Documentation.

Following these steps ensures that your AWS MSK cluster remains accessible to legitimate clients while adhering to security best practices as outlined in the AWS documentation. For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the AWS official documentation on changing security groups: Change Security Group for AWS MSK.
