countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

reference.name: CWE-319: CWE-319

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

component.name: Application Load Balancer
component.desc: Elastic Load Balancer that distributes incoming application traffic across multiple targets.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-695
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-695: Use of Low-Level Functionality The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms, introduce exploitable inconsistencies, or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Activate deletion protection for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Enable deletion protection on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to prevent accidental or unauthorized removal of the load balancer. This setting adds an additional layer of security by ensuring that critical load balancer configurations cannot be deleted without explicit authorization. Activating deletion protection helps safeguard against human error, malicious actions, and potential service disruptions. Regularly review the status of deletion protection to confirm it remains enabled, ensuring continuous protection of your ALB and the applications it supports.

countermeasure.name: Configure strictest desync mitigation mode for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Set your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to operate using the strictest desynchronization (desync) mitigation mode available. This configuration helps defend against HTTP request smuggling and other desynchronization attacks that can exploit differences in how HTTP requests are processed between clients and servers. By enabling the strictest desync mitigation mode, you ensure that the ALB consistently handles incoming traffic in a secure manner, reducing the risk of these attacks and maintaining the integrity of data transmission. Regularly review and update this setting to align with best practices and evolving security threats.

countermeasure.name: Deploy AWS WAF with managed rules to protect applications behind your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Implement AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) in conjunction with your AWS Application Load Balancer to protect web applications from common web exploits and vulnerabilities. Utilize AWS WAF's managed rule sets to automatically block known threats, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and other common attacks, before they reach your application. Configure and customize WAF rules based on the specific needs of your application to ensure comprehensive protection. Regularly review and update the WAF rules to adapt to new threats and application changes, ensuring continuous security. Integrate WAF logging with AWS CloudWatch for monitoring and alerting on suspicious activity.

reference.name: Web Application Firewall, Web API Protection - AWS WAF

countermeasure.name: Enable access logging for your Application Load Balancer and integrate with CloudWatch and CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc: Enable access logging on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to capture detailed records of all incoming traffic. Integrate these logs with AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for suspicious activities and unauthorized access attempts. Set up automated alerts within CloudWatch to notify your team of any anomalies or potential security incidents. Regularly review the access logs to identify patterns or activities that may indicate security threats, and take proactive measures to address any identified risks. This control ensures that all traffic through the ALB is tracked and analyzed, enhancing the security and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable access logs for your Application Load Balancer

countermeasure.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that cross-zone load balancing is enabled on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to evenly distribute incoming traffic across all available zones within the region. This configuration enhances fault tolerance by preventing any single availability zone from becoming a bottleneck or single point of failure. It also improves resource efficiency by balancing the load across multiple zones, ensuring optimal performance and reducing the risk of overloading individual resources. Regularly verify that cross-zone load balancing is enabled and functioning as intended to maintain high availability and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental or malicious deletion of Load Balancer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Accidental or malicious deletion of an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) occurs when the load balancer is unintentionally or deliberately removed, disrupting traffic distribution and causing service outages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Human Error: Mistaken deletion during routine tasks.
  • Malicious Insider: An authorized user intentionally deletes the ALB.
  • Compromised Credentials: Attackers gain unauthorized access and delete the ALB.

Impacts

  • Service Downtime: Immediate interruption in traffic routing, leading to application unavailability.
  • Revenue Loss: Downtime can lead to financial losses and damage to customer trust.
  • Operational Disruption: Resources are diverted to restore service, causing further delays.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental Deletion: An admin mistakenly deletes the ALB during maintenance, causing downtime until reconfiguration.
  2. Malicious Insider: A disgruntled employee deletes the ALB to cause service outages.
  3. Credential Compromise: An attacker deletes the ALB after gaining unauthorized access to the AWS console.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Lack of logging and monitoring in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the absence or inadequacy of tracking and reviewing activities related to the ALB. Without proper logging, security incidents, misconfigurations, or unauthorized access attempts may go undetected, leaving the system vulnerable to prolonged risks and making it difficult to investigate incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Logging and monitoring features not properly enabled or configured.
  • Negligence: Failure to regularly review logs or set up alerts for suspicious activities.
  • Malicious Actors: Exploiting the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.

Impacts

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Without logs, security breaches can go unnoticed.
  • Difficulty in Incident Response: Lack of detailed logs complicates forensic investigations and response efforts.
  • Non-Compliance: Failure to maintain proper logging may lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Breach: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an application behind the ALB, but due to lack of logging, the breach remains unnoticed for an extended period.
  2. Misconfiguration Overlooked: A misconfiguration in the ALB allows traffic that should have been blocked. Without monitoring, this issue persists, exposing the application to potential attacks.
  3. Failed Audit: During a compliance audit, the organization fails to provide adequate logs for the ALB, leading to penalties or loss of certification.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure cross-zone Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure cross-zone load balancing in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the improper configuration of traffic distribution across multiple availability zones. If cross-zone load balancing is not enabled or is misconfigured, traffic may be unevenly distributed, leading to potential single points of failure, inefficient resource utilization, and reduced fault tolerance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Failure to enable cross-zone load balancing or incorrect settings that prevent proper traffic distribution.
  • Resource Limitations: Uneven distribution of traffic that causes some zones to be overburdened while others remain underutilized.
  • Fault Tolerance Issues: Lack of redundancy due to improper load balancing can make the system vulnerable to zone failures.

Impacts

  • Single Points of Failure: Without proper cross-zone balancing, a failure in a heavily burdened zone can lead to significant service disruption.
  • Inefficient Resource Utilization: Overloaded zones can lead to poor performance and increased latency, while underutilized zones waste resources.
  • Reduced Fault Tolerance: The inability to distribute traffic evenly across zones can reduce the overall fault tolerance of the application, making it more susceptible to outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Zone Failure: Cross-zone load balancing is disabled, and most traffic is routed to a single availability zone. When that zone experiences an outage, the application becomes unavailable.
  2. Performance Degradation: A misconfigured ALB routes most traffic to one zone, overloading instances in that zone while instances in other zones remain idle, leading to slow response times and poor user experience.
  3. Increased Latency: Due to improper load balancing, some users experience higher latency because their requests are handled by overburdened instances in a particular zone, while other instances are underused.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in web applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerabilities in web applications behind an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refer to security weaknesses in the applications that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may include SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), insecure deserialization, and other common web application flaws. If not properly mitigated, these vulnerabilities can be exploited to compromise the application, steal data, or gain unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers actively scan for and exploit vulnerabilities in web applications to gain unauthorized access or cause harm.
  • Automated Bots: Bots can systematically probe web applications for known vulnerabilities and exploit them if found.
  • Inadequate Security Practices: Development teams may inadvertently introduce vulnerabilities through coding errors or inadequate security testing.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information may be accessed or stolen, leading to significant financial and reputational damage.
  • Application Compromise: Attackers can gain control over the application, altering functionality or using it as a launching point for further attacks.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Exploited vulnerabilities can result in violations of data protection regulations, leading to fines and penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SQL Injection: An attacker exploits a SQL injection vulnerability in the web application to access the backend database, stealing sensitive user information.
  2. Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): An attacker injects malicious scripts into a vulnerable web application, which are then executed in the browsers of unsuspecting users, leading to data theft or session hijacking.
  3. Insecure Deserialization: A vulnerability in the applications deserialization process is exploited by an attacker to execute arbitrary code, leading to complete system compromise.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Desynchronization attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Desynchronization attacks on AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) involve manipulating the sequence or synchronization of HTTP requests and responses, leading to vulnerabilities like HTTP request smuggling. These attacks can allow malicious actors to bypass security controls, inject malicious payloads, or interfere with normal application operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers exploit gaps in how the ALB processes and synchronizes HTTP requests and responses.
  • Misconfiguration: Improper settings in the ALB that allow desync vulnerabilities to be exploited.
  • Complex Web Traffic: Applications with complex, multi-part requests that are more susceptible to desync issues.

Impacts

  • Bypassed Security Controls: Attackers can bypass firewalls or WAF rules, leading to potential data breaches or unauthorized actions.
  • Request Smuggling: Malicious actors can manipulate HTTP requests to perform actions they shouldn't be allowed to.
  • Service Disruption: Desync attacks can cause disruptions in how applications process web traffic, potentially leading to outages or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Request Smuggling: An attacker sends a specially crafted HTTP request that takes advantage of desynchronization, bypassing the WAF and gaining unauthorized access to sensitive application areas.
  2. Bypass Security Filters: Due to a desync issue, a malicious payload is able to slip through security filters that would normally block it, leading to data exfiltration.
  3. Service Degradation: A desynchronization attack causes the ALB to misroute traffic, leading to significant delays and potential service outages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-1188
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1188: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enable termination protection on production or critical CloudFormation stacks
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on stack termination protection for every CloudFormation stack that hosts production or otherwise business-critical resources. Termination protection prevents an accidental DeleteStack operationwhether issued from the console, CLI, API, or by an automated pipelinefrom tearing down live infrastructure.

How to implement

  1. During stack creation
    • Console: Create stack Configure stack options check Enable termination protection.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
    • aws cloudformation create-stack \
       --stack-name prod-network \
       --enable-termination-protection \
       --template-body file://network.yml
  2. For existing stacks
  3. aws cloudformation update-termination-protection \
     --stack-name prod-network \
     --enable-termination-protection
  4. Guardrails
    • Embed TerminationProtection: true or the corresponding CLI flag in every production pipeline so the protection cant be skipped by mistake.
    • Add an SCP or IAM policy that denies cloudformation:DeleteStack unless the request includes the condition aws:RequestTag{"Environment":"Sandbox"}.
    • Use AWS Config rule cloudformation-termination-protection-enabled (or a custom rule) to alert if a critical stack lacks the setting.
  5. Operational procedure
    • If you truly need to remove a protected stack, require a two-person review to first disable termination protection and then run the delete.
    • Log both actions with CloudTrail and notify the Security or SRE channel via EventBridge SNS.

Enabling termination protection provides a simple but highly effective safeguard against catastrophic, irreversible deletions in production accounts.

References

  • Protect a stack from being accidentally deleted (AWS CloudFormation)

countermeasure.name: Ensure templates containing sensitive information are stored securely
countermeasure.desc:
Any CloudFormation template that contains secrets, connection strings, or architecture details must reside only in encrypted storage with tightly scoped access:

  1. Choose an encrypted repository
    • CodeCommit (encrypted at rest with AWS-owned KMS keys), an S3 bucket with SSE-KMS, or a Git service hosted inside an encrypted EBS/EFS volume.
  2. Lock down access
    • Grant least-privilege IAM permissionsread/write only to DevOps roles and your CI/CD service role.
    • Require MFA for console access and Git pushes; enable branch protection to stop force-pushes or secret rewrites.
  3. Encrypt in transit
    • Enforce HTTPS/TLS for Git and S3; block HTTP with bucket policies ("aws:SecureTransport":"false").
  4. Remove or externalize secrets
    • Reference sensitive values through SSM Parameter Store or Secrets Manager parameters rather than hard-coding them.
    • If a template must embed data (for example, a Lambda ZIP hash), encrypt the file using AWS KMS-encrypted artifacts before storing.
  5. Continuous monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules (or Git hooks) that flag unencrypted buckets or repositories with public access.
    • Run secret-scanning tools (git-secrets, truffleHog) in your pipeline; fail builds if new credentials appear.
  6. Audit & rotate
    • Quarterly, review repository IAM policies and KMS key policies; rotate encryption keys per compliance policy.
    • Use CloudTrail and CodeCommit access logs to detect unusual reads or clones.

Securing storage for sensitive templates prevents credential leakage, intellectual-property exposure, and supply-chain tampering before infrastructure is even deployed.

References

  • Protect sensitive data in CloudFormation templates AWS Docs
  • Encrypt and control access to CodeCommit and S3 repositories

countermeasure.name: Implement code review processes for CloudFormation templates
countermeasure.desc:
Treat every CloudFormation template like application code: commit it to version control and block deployment until it has passed an automated scan and been approved by at least one qualified reviewer.

Implementation guidance

  1. Source-control first Store templates in a Git repository (AWS CodeCommit, GitHub, Bitbucket). Enable branch-protection rules that:
    • Force pull requests (PRs) for every change.
    • Require a minimum of one reviewer for dev stacks and two for production-bound stacks.
    • Block direct pushes to the main or release branches.
  2. Automated checks in the PR pipeline
    • Run cfn-lint to catch syntax errors and IAM typo-policies.
    • Run CloudFormation Guard or cfn-nag rules to enforce organisational policies (for example, no public S3 buckets, encryption required, termination protection enabled).
    • Fail the PR if any check returns a non-zero exit code.
  3. Human review focus areas
    • Validate logical changes (new resources, deletions, capability flags).
    • Confirm IAM policies are least-privilege and scoped to specific ARNs.
    • Ensure parameters do not hard-code secretsuse SSM or Secrets Manager instead.
    • Verify that stack tags include environment, owner, and cost-centre metadata.
  4. Merge & deploy
    • After approvals and green checks, merge to the protected branch that triggers the deployment pipeline (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions, etc.).
    • Require a second approval or change-control ticket when the pipeline targets a production account.
  5. Continuous improvement
    • Review rejected PRs quarterly to refine linter rules.
    • Rotate reviewers to avoid knowledge silos and keep security knowledge current.

A disciplined review workflow catches misconfigurations and privilege-escalation paths early, preventing insecure infrastructure from ever reaching an AWS account.

References

  • AWS CloudFormation security best practices treat templates as code
  • AWS CloudFormation Guard policy as code for template validation

countermeasure.name: Store CloudFormation templates in S3 buckets configured with server-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
When you keep packaged CloudFormation templates ( .yaml, .json, or ZIP archives referenced with TemplateURL and AWS::Include ) in Amazon S3, place them only in buckets that use server-side encryption (SSE):

  1. Choose the encryption mode
    • SSE-KMS with a customer-managed key (recommended) for full control over key rotation and granular access via key policy.
    • SSE-S3 if you do not need separate key management but still want 256-bit encryption at rest.
  2. Configure the bucket
    • In the console: Properties Default encryption Enable and select AWS KMS key or SSE-S3.
    • With the CLI:
      • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
         --bucket cf-templates-prod \
         --server-side-encryption-configuration \
         '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":{"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/cfn-templates"}}]}'
  3. Block plaintext uploads with a bucket policy that denies s3:PutObject when the request lacks encryption headers:
    1. {
       "Sid":"DenyUnencryptedObjectUploads",
       "Effect":"Deny",
       "Principal":"*",
       "Action":"s3:PutObject",
       "Resource":"arn:aws:s3:::cf-templates-prod/*",
       "Condition":{"StringNotEquals":{"s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption":"aws:kms"}}
      }
  4. Restrict access
    • Grant read permissions only to the CI/CD role that packages or validates templates and the CloudFormation service principal in the target account.
    • Enable Bucket Versioning and MFA delete to protect against overwrites and accidental removals.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Deploy the AWS Config managed rule s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled (or a custom rule scoped to template buckets) so any unencrypted object or new bucket triggers an alert.
    • Include secret-scanning tools in the pipeline to ensure sensitive data is not stored in plaintext inside the templates themselves.

Securing template artifacts with SSE guarantees that infrastructure code is encrypted at rest, satisfies compliance frameworks requiring data-at-rest protection, and prevents inadvertent exposure if the bucket or snapshots are copied elsewhere.

References

  • Protecting data at rest using server-side encryption Amazon S3

countermeasure.name: Use CloudFormation drift detection regularly
countermeasure.desc:
Schedule an automated workflow that runs CloudFormation drift detection on every production or compliance-sensitive stack (for example, nightly or after each deployment). Detecting drift early reveals unapproved manual changessuch as altered security-group rules, missing resources, or changed IAM policiesso you can remediate before they become security incidents.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the scan
    • Use an EventBridge rule or CI/CD job that calls aws cloudformation detect-stack-drift --stack-name <stack> for each critical stack.
    • Capture the returned drift detection ID, then poll describe-stack-drift-detection-status until DetectionStatus is DETECTION_COMPLETE.
  2. Alert on drift
    • If StackDriftStatus equals DRIFTED, publish a message to an SNS topic tied to your on-call or ticketing system. Include a link to the consoles Drift details page for fastest triage.
  3. Establish remediation procedures
    • Legitimate change? Update the template and re-deploy so CloudFormation regains control.
    • Unapproved change? Roll back manually or use cloudformation update-stack with the original template.
  4. Harden against future drift
    • Enforce IAM least privilege so only CI/CD roles can mutate stack resources.
    • Enable stack termination protection and lock down the consoles/CLI in production accounts.
  5. Report & audit
    • Store drift results in an S3 bucket or Security Lake for compliance evidence.
    • Review quarterly to confirm scan cadence, add new stacks, and refine alert thresholds.

Regular drift detection keeps your live environment faithful to the version-controlled template, prevents configuration creep, and supports audit requirements for change control.

References

  • Detecting unmanaged configuration changes with CloudFormation drift detection
  • Automating drift detection with AWS CloudFormation and EventBridg

countermeasure.name: Use IAM condition keys to restrict which templates can be used
countermeasure.desc:
Limit stack and change-set operations so they can only use templates stored in your approved S3 locations (or specific signed URLs) by adding the cloudformation:TemplateURL condition key to every IAM policy, role, or Service Control Policy (SCP) that allows cloudformation:CreateStack*, cloudformation:UpdateStack*, or cloudformation:CreateChangeSet.

Implementation steps

  1. Pick the allowed repositories e.g., an SSE-KMSencrypted bucket cf-templates-prod-<acct-id> and, if needed, a staging bucket for non-prod.
  2. Author the policy
    1. {
       "Version": "2012-10-17",
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": [
             "cloudformation:CreateStack",
             "cloudformation:UpdateStack",
             "cloudformation:CreateChangeSet"
           ],
           "Resource": "*",
           "Condition": {
             "StringLike": {
               "cloudformation:TemplateURL": [
                 "https://cf-templates-prod-123456789012.s3.amazonaws.com/*"
               ]
             }
           }
         }
       ]
      }
  3. Use StringEquals for exact URLs or StringLike with wildcards for a bucket prefix.
  4. Attach where it matters
    • Production deployment role.
    • CI/CD service role.
    • An organization-wide SCP to stop rogue console/API usage in member accounts.
  5. Block inline templates if required add a Deny statement for RequestTag{"cfn-inline":"true"} or detect the absence of cloudformation:TemplateURL via Null conditions.
  6. Test attempt to deploy a stack that points to an unapproved bucket; the call should fail with AccessDenied (error code ThrottlingException / AccessDenied).
  7. Monitor & review use CloudTrail Lake or Athena to query for cloudformation:CreateStack events where requestParameters.templateURL does not start with your bucket path, and alert if any are found.

Enforcing this condition key stops attackersor well-meaning but careless engineersfrom importing templates that were never peer-reviewed, scanned, or stored in your controlled repository.

References

  • IAM condition keys for AWS CloudFormation

countermeasure.name: Use linting tools and SAST tools to scan templates for potential security misconfigurations
countermeasure.desc:
Add an automated stage to every CI/CD pipeline that runs infrastructure-as-code (IaC) linters and static application security-testing (SAST) tools against your CloudFormation templates. This stage blocks the merge or deployment if it detects syntax errors, insecure defaults, or policy violations.

Implementation guidance

  1. Select your scanners
    • cfn-lint for specification and regional-rule validation.
    • CloudFormation Guard (cfn-guard) or cfn-nag / Checkov / Snyk IaC for security and compliance rules (encryption required, no public resources, least-privilege IAM, etc.).
  2. Integrate into the pipeline
    • Add a dedicated Template Scan job in CodeBuild, GitHub Actions, or your chosen runner.
    • Fail the build on any ERROR from cfn-lint or any rule violation from the SAST toolset. Publish human-readable reports in the PR for reviewers.
  3. Maintain a rules repository
    • Store custom Guard or Nag rules in version control alongside the templates, and review them just like code.
    • Tag each rule with severity so non-blocking WARN findings dont halt lower-environment builds but still surface in reports.
  4. Continuously improve
    • Track recurring findings; harden your base modules so the same issue stops appearing.
    • Update tool versions and rule packs regularlyespecially after new AWS services or vulnerabilities are announced.
  5. Audit & alert
    • Export scan results to Security Hub or a central dashboard so security teams can spot trends.
    • Require an exception ticket, signed off by a security lead, for any deployment that must bypass a critical finding.

By enforcing automated linting and security scanning, you catch misconfigurationslike open security groups, unencrypted storage, or overly broad IAM policiesbefore they ever reach an AWS account, greatly reducing the risk of production vulnerabilities.

References

  • CloudFormation Guard policy-as-code for security & compliance

SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Use NoEcho property for CloudFormation to mask the value in logs and console
countermeasure.desc:
When a CloudFormation template needs a secretsuch as a database password, API key, or license tokendeclare it as a Parameter and set NoEcho: true. CloudFormation will replace the value with asterisks ( ***** ) in the console, CLI, SDK responses, and CloudTrail logs, preventing accidental exposure.

Implementation steps

  1. Define the parameter
    1. Parameters:
       DbPassword:
         Type: String
         NoEcho: true
         Description: "RDS master password (will be masked)"
  2. Reference the parameter wherever the secret is required (for example, in AWS::RDS::DBInstance MasterUserPassword).
  3. Pass the value securely at deploy time:
    • CLI: aws cloudformation create-stack --parameters ParameterKey=DbPassword,ParameterValue="$(aws secretsmanager get-secret-value )"
    • CI/CD: read from Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store and inject via a secure variable.
  4. Understand the limits NoEcho masks values in stack descriptions and events but does not hide data you copy into the Metadata or Outputs sections; never echo secrets there.
  5. Enforce in review pipelines add a lint rule (cfn-guard, cfn-nag) that fails the build if any parameter whose name contains Password, Token, or Secret lacks NoEcho: true.

Using NoEcho ensures that sensitive inputs stay confidential throughout the stack life-cycle while still letting templates remain fully declarative.

References

  • CloudFormation parameters syntax
  • General template snippets

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use stack policies with Deny statements for the Update:Delete or Delete actions
countermeasure.desc:
Attach a CloudFormation stack policy to every production or high-value stack that explicitly denies the actions Update:Delete, Update:Replace, and Delete for the resources you cannot afford to lose (for example, stateful databases, KMS keys, or VPCs). This prevents accidental or malicious template updates from tearing down or replacing critical infrastructure.

Implementation steps

  1. Author the policy JSON start with a blanket deny that blocks destructive updates, then whitelist resources that may be safely replaced:
    1. {
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Deny",
           "Action": [ "Update:*", "Delete:*" ],
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": "*"
         },
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": "Update:*",
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": [
             "LogicalResourceId/StatelessALB",
             "LogicalResourceId/LambdaFunction*"
           ]
         }
       ]
      }
  2. Apply the policy
    • At creation:
      • aws cloudformation create-stack \
         --stack-name prod-app \
         --template-body file://template.yml \
         --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
    • On existing stacks:
      aws cloudformation set-stack-policy --stack-name prod-app --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
  3. Override only when necessary if a legitimate change needs to modify a protected resource, supply a temporary update-time policy with --stack-policy-during-update-body, execute the update, then restore the original deny policy.
  4. Automate and audit
    • Bake the policy file into your IaC repo and apply it automatically in your deployment pipeline.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule (or Security Hub control) that flags stacks whose StackPolicy property is null or differs from the approved baseline.
    • Monitor CloudTrail for SetStackPolicy, UpdateStack, or DeleteStack events and alert on any operation that first removes the deny rules.

Using deny-first stack policies adds a hardened guardrail: even if someone has UpdateStack or DeleteStack permission, CloudFormation itself will refuse operations that could delete or replace protected resources unless a controlled override is in place.

References

  • Prevent updates to stack resources with stack policies
  • Configuring stack policies for least privilege

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion of critical infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unintentional removal of CloudFormation stacks or resourcesdue to manual errors, template misconfigurations, or faulty automationcan destroy critical infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Negligent admins running DeleteStack on the wrong environment
  • Templates or change sets lacking Retain policies
  • CI/CD pipelines applying malformed updates or drift-remediation scripts

Impacts

  • Immediate service outages
  • Irretrievable data loss
  • Extended recovery times and SLA breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An operator accidentally deletes the prod stack instead of dev in the console.
  2. A template update omits DeletionPolicy: Retain on an RDS instance, causing its deletion during deployment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized stack operations by overly permissive IAM principals
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When IAM principals (users, roles, or service accounts) have overly broad CloudFormation permissionssuch as cloudformation:* on *they can perform stack operations (create, update, delete) beyond their legitimate scope, leading to unauthorized modifications or destruction of infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and overlyprivileged automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Wildcard IAM policies granting cloudformation:* on all resources.
    • Misscoped servicelinked roles or crossaccount trusts.
    • Phishing or exploit of privileged accounts to gain leftover CloudFormation rights.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Resource Changes: Creation of malicious stacks or deletion of critical ones.
  • Data Loss & Outages: Destruction of databases, networking, or compute resources.
  • Cost Overruns: Spinning up expensive infrastructure.
  • Compliance Failures: Untracked changes breach audit requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Role Abuse: An attacker who phishes a DevOps engineers credentials uses their cloudformation:* role to delete production stacks.
  2. Automation Misconfiguration: A CI/CD service role with unrestricted stackupdate rights is hijacked to inject backdoored resources.
  3. CrossAccount Exploit: Overly permissive crossaccount trust lets an external AWS account delete your critical stacks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data embedded or passed insecurely into templates
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Embedding secrets (passwords, API keys, certificates) directly in CloudFormation templatesor passing them via unsecured parametersexposes sensitive data whenever those templates are accessed, versioned, or logged.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Checking templates with hardcoded secrets into code repos or public S3 buckets
    • Passing plaintext parameters in CLI/console history or CloudTrail logs
    • Exporting stack parameters to logs or notifications without redaction

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Attackers obtain credentials to pivot into other systems
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of datahandling mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA)
  • Attack Facilitation: Exposed infrastructure details enable targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A developer commits a template containing an RDS master password to GitHub; attackers clone it and connect to the database.
  2. An automated deployment logs parameter values (including API tokens) in CloudWatch; a malicious insider reads the logs to harvest credentials.
  3. A CloudFormation change notification emails full parameter sets to a distribution list, inadvertently revealing SSH keys to unauthorized recipients.

threat.name: Disclosure of template content stored insecurely
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
CloudFormation templates often embed parameters, mappings, or metadata. If these templates are stored without proper access controls or encryptionsuch as in public S3 buckets or unsecured code reposattackers can retrieve sensitive data or infrastructure details.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Public or misconfigured S3 buckets containing templates
    • Sourcecontrol repositories with weak permissions
    • CI/CD artifacts exposed via unsecured artifact stores

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Hardcoded passwords, keys, or ARNs are exposed
  • Reconnaissance: Attackers learn infrastructure topology and roles
  • Attack Facilitation: Sensitive parameters guide targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A public S3 bucket used for template storage is crawled by an attacker, who downloads a template containing database passwords.
  2. A GitHub repo with lax permissions leaks templates embedding IAM role ARNs and EC2 instance IDs, enabling precise phishing.
  3. A CI pipelines artifact store exposes unencrypted templates; a malicious insider retrieves them to map out VPC and subnet configurations for later intrusion.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Deployment of insecure or malicious infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Provisioning resources via compromised or poorly vetted CloudFormation templates can spin up insecure or malicious infrastructuresuch as open firewalls, backdoored compute, or overly permissive IAM rolesundermining your security posture from the outset.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD pipelines, supplychain attackers
  • Attack Vectors: Injecting malicious code into shared templates; using untrusted community templates; hijacking template repositories or artifact stores

Impacts

  • Backdoor Access: Attackercontrolled instances or management interfaces
  • Privilege Escalation: Overly broad IAM roles grant unintended rights
  • Data Exposure & Exfiltration: Open storage buckets or network ports leak sensitive data
  • Persistence: Malicious resources remain hidden in IaC until redeployment

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A CI pipeline pulls a tampered template that creates an EC2 instance with a backdoor user account, giving the attacker remote shell access.
  2. A team uses an Internet-sourced VPC template that unintentionally opens all subnets to the Internet, exposing databases and admin APIs.
  3. An attacker compromises the template artifact store and injects a Lambda function with wide iam:PassRole permissions, allowing escalation to full-account takeover.

threat.name: Configuration drift leading to insecure or unknown states
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Configuration drift occurs when live AWS resources diverge from their CloudFormation templates due to outofband changes. This unsynchronized state can introduce insecure settings, orphaned resources, or unknown dependencies that arent captured in your infrastructure as code.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, DevOps engineers making ad hoc fixes, and rogue automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Manual console edits to security groups, IAM policies, or resource properties without updating the stack.
    • External tools or scripts provisioning resources outside CloudFormation.
    • Forgotten template updates after patching or scaling activities.

Impacts

  • Security Gaps: Unintended open ports, weak encryption settings, or outdated AMIs introduce vulnerabilities.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Drifted resources fall out of alignment with approved configurations, breaking governance.
  • Operational Uncertainty: Stack updates or deletions may fail or revert critical live changes, increasing downtime and risk.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Orphaned SSH Access: A support engineer opens SSH on a production EC2 security group for troubleshooting but never updates the templateleaving the instance exposed long term.
  2. Untracked Snapshot Creation: Automated backup scripts create EBS snapshots outside of CF; when the stack is deleted, these snapshots persist, revealing sensitive data.
  3. Vulnerable AMI Drift: A manual patch replaces CF-managed instances with a new AMI; the template still references the old, vulnerable AMI, causing future rollbacks to redeploy insecure hosts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1612 - Build Image on Host

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Avoid sensitive information in tags and free-form text fields
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain the security and privacy of your AWS DeepComposer environment, ensure that confidential or sensitive information is not included in tags or free-form text fields such as Name fields. This practice helps prevent accidental exposure of sensitive data in logs, diagnostics, or billing records.

Implementation Steps:

Define Data Handling Policies: Establish clear policies that prohibit the inclusion of sensitive information in tags or free-form text fields. Communicate these policies to all team members.

Implement Validation Checks: Use automated scripts or AWS Lambda functions to scan tags and free-form text fields for sensitive data patterns and alert administrators if any are found.

Review and Audit: Regularly review and audit tags and free-form text fields to ensure compliance with data handling policies. Remove or redact any sensitive information that is identified.

User Training: Educate developers and administrators about the risks of including sensitive information in tags and text fields, emphasizing the importance of adhering to established data handling policies.

countermeasure.name: Implement IAM policies with resource conditions
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS DeepComposer pipeline resources, implement IAM policies that include specific resource conditions such as datapipeline:PipelineCreator and datapipeline:Tag. These conditions help control access by ensuring that only authorized users can create, modify, or tag pipeline resources, thereby enhancing security and preventing unauthorized modifications.

Implementation Steps:

Define IAM Policies: Create IAM policies that specify conditions for accessing pipeline resources. Use resource conditions like datapipeline:PipelineCreator and datapipeline:Tag to limit actions to authorized users.

Attach Policies to Roles: Assign these IAM policies to appropriate roles or user groups that need access to pipeline resources. Ensure that roles are granted the minimum necessary permissions.

Audit and Review: Regularly audit IAM policies and roles to verify that the conditions are correctly implemented and that only authorized users have access to sensitive operations.

Monitoring and Alerts: Set up monitoring and alerts for any policy violations or attempts to access pipeline resources without proper authorization. Use AWS CloudTrail and CloudWatch for continuous monitoring.

countermeasure.name: Properly configure and assign worker groups
countermeasure.desc:
To avoid inefficiencies and vulnerabilities in AWS DeepComposer, ensure that worker groups are properly configured and assigned to the appropriate tasks. This control helps maintain optimal performance and security by ensuring that worker groups are correctly defined and utilized.

Implementation Steps:

Define Worker Group Configurations: Establish clear definitions and configurations for worker groups based on the specific requirements of your tasks. Ensure that each worker group has the necessary resources and permissions.

  • Define configurations such as instance types, resource limits, and access controls for each worker group.

Assign Tasks Appropriately: Assign tasks to worker groups based on their configurations and capabilities. Ensure that each task is handled by the most suitable worker group to optimize performance and security.

  • Match tasks to worker groups that are specifically configured to handle their requirements.

Regularly Review Configurations: Periodically review worker group configurations and task assignments to ensure they remain appropriate and effective. Adjust configurations as necessary to accommodate changes in workload or task requirements.

  • Schedule regular audits and updates to worker group configurations.

Monitor and Adjust: Continuously monitor the performance and security of worker groups. Use AWS CloudWatch and other monitoring tools to track resource utilization and detect any inefficiencies or vulnerabilities.

  • Set up alerts to notify administrators of any issues that require attention.

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to execution logs using IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your AWS DeepComposer environment, restrict access to execution logs by applying appropriate AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies. This control limits access to only authorized users, preventing unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Define IAM Policies: Create policies that grant specific permissions to view or modify DeepComposer execution logs, following the principle of least privilege.

Assign IAM Roles: Attach these IAM policies to roles or user groups that require access to the execution logs.

Audit and Review Access: Regularly audit roles and policies to ensure only authorized users have access, removing unnecessary permissions as needed.

Enable Logging and Monitoring: Use AWS CloudWatch Logs to capture and store execution logs securely. Set retention policies and configure alerts for unauthorized access attempts.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Use AWS STS for temporary security credentials
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security in AWS DeepComposer, utilize AWS Security Token Service (STS) to generate temporary security credentials. Ensure these credentials are securely handled to prevent unauthorized access and misuse. Temporary credentials reduce the risk associated with long-term credentials by providing short-lived, limited-privilege access.

Implementation Steps:

Generate Temporary Credentials: Use AWS STS to generate temporary security credentials (access key ID, secret access key, and session token) with a defined expiration time.

  • Configure policies to specify the duration and permissions of temporary credentials.

Integrate with Applications: Update your applications and services to request and use temporary credentials from AWS STS. Ensure these credentials are rotated regularly.

  • Modify your applications to use the AssumeRole API or other STS operations to obtain credentials dynamically.

Secure Storage and Transmission: Ensure that temporary credentials are securely stored and transmitted. Use environment variables or secure storage solutions like AWS Secrets Manager to handle credentials.

  • Encrypt credentials at rest and in transit using appropriate security measures.

Monitor and Revoke Access: Continuously monitor the usage of temporary credentials and promptly revoke access if suspicious activity is detected. Use AWS CloudTrail to log and audit the use of STS credentials.

  • Set up alerts for unusual access patterns or anomalies in credential usage.

Educate and Enforce Best Practices: Train developers and administrators on the importance of using temporary credentials and best practices for handling them securely.

  • Conduct regular training sessions and provide documentation on secure credential management.

countermeasure.name: Validate pipeline definitions
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that AWS DeepComposer pipeline definitions are well-formed and error-free, utilize the ValidatePipelineDefinition action. This control verifies the integrity and correctness of pipeline definitions, preventing execution failures and ensuring smooth operation of machine learning workflows.

Implementation Steps:

Integrate Validation in Workflow: Incorporate the ValidatePipelineDefinition action into your deployment pipeline to automatically validate definitions before they are executed.

  • Ensure that this validation step is mandatory and occurs prior to pipeline activation.

Automate Validation Checks: Use automated scripts or CI/CD tools to trigger ValidatePipelineDefinition as part of the pipeline deployment process.

  • Configure these tools to halt the deployment if validation fails, ensuring only correct definitions proceed.

Error Handling and Notifications: Implement error handling to capture validation errors and notify relevant stakeholders.

  • Use AWS CloudWatch or other monitoring tools to log validation results and alert developers of any issues.

Regular Audits: Periodically review and audit pipeline definitions to ensure they remain well-formed and adhere to best practices.

  • Schedule regular audits and update validation checks as needed to accommodate changes in pipeline requirements.
