usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Define IAM policies for Distributed Map state
countermeasure.desc: When you create workflows with the Step Functions console, Step Functions can automatically generate IAM policies based on the resources in your workflow definition. These policies include the least privileges necessary to allow the state machine role to invoke the StartExecution API action for the Distributed Map state. These policies also include the least privileges necessary Step Functions to access AWS resources, such as Amazon S3 buckets and objects and Lambda functions. We highly recommend that you include only those permissions that are necessary in your IAM policies. For example, if your workflow includes a Map state in Distributed mode, scope your policies down to the specific Amazon S3 bucket and folder that contains your dataset.

reference.name: CWE-284: CWE-284
IAM policies for using Distributed Map state

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Do not put sensitive data into AWS Step Functions free-form fields
countermeasure.desc: Do not put sensitive identifying information, such as your customers' email addresses, into tags or free-form text fields such as a Name field. This includes when you work with Step Functions or other AWS services using the console, API, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs. Any data that you enter into tags or free-form text fields used for names may be used for billing or diagnostic logs. If you provide a URL to an external server, we strongly recommend that you do not include credentials information in the URL to validate your request to that server.

reference.name: CWE-200: CWE-200
Data protection in AWS Step Functions

AU-6 Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting

countermeasure.name: Use VPC Endpoints to ensure Step Functions communicate with other services securely
countermeasure.desc:
If you use Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) to host your AWS resources, you can establish a connection between your Amazon VPC and AWS Step Functions workflows. You can use this connection with your Step Functions workflows without crossing the public internet. Amazon VPC endpoints are supported by Standard Workflows, Express Workflows, and Synchronous Express Workflows.

Amazon VPC lets you launch AWS resources in a custom virtual network. You can use a VPC to control your network settings, such as the IP address range, subnets, route tables, and network gateways. For more information about VPCs, see the Amazon VPC User Guide.

To connect your Amazon VPC to Step Functions, you must first define an interface VPC endpoint, which lets you connect your VPC to other AWS services. The endpoint provides reliable, scalable connectivity, without requiring an internet gateway, network address translation (NAT) instance, or VPN connection. For more information, see Interface VPC Endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) in the Amazon VPC User Guide.

reference.name: Amazon VPC Endpoints for Step Functions
CWE-200: CWE-200

PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

countermeasure.name: Use WS User Notifications with Step Functions
countermeasure.desc: You can use AWS User Notifications to receive alerts and notifications for security-related events in Step Functions. You receive a notification when an event matches a rule that you specify. You can receive notifications for events through multiple channels, including email, AWS Chatbot chat notifications, or AWS Console Mobile Application push notifications. You can also see notifications in the Console Notifications Center. User Notifications supports aggregation, which can reduce the number of notifications you receive during specific events.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Uncontrolled parallel workloads
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat refers to the scenario where an excessively high amount of parallel workloads are implemented without proper control or management. Such a situation can stress the resources and infrastructure, yielding increased costs and weak performance.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfiguration is a common cause of this threat. It could be due to inadvertent errors by administrators failing to manage the workload effectively. Alternatively, malicious actors might manipulate the workload configuration to initiate a Denial of Service (DoS) attack.
Impacts
Overloading the system with uncontrolled parallel workloads can cause excessive resource utilization, leading to severe system slowdown or potential downtime. In a pay-as-you-go environment like AWS, it may result in significant unexpected costs. Besides, it may impact the service availability negatively, disrupting business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An accidental misconfiguration by an admin can trigger a mass parallel execution of workloads that exceed the set limits, straining the resources and causing potential unavailability of services. Another scenario could be a malicious internal user or hacker who intentionally modifies the configuration to initiate uncontrolled parallel execution, resulting in a DoS attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Unsecured communication with AWS Services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unsecured Communication with AWS Services refers to a situation wherein the communication between the AWS Step Functions and other AWS services is not properly encrypted or secured. This could potentially expose sensitive data in transit, or allow unauthorized modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This vulnerability can be exploited by cyber attackers who intercept the communication between AWS services. They can do so through man-in-the-middle attacks, traffic sniffing, or even through accessing insecure network configurations.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breach, unexpected charges from compromised AWS resources, loss of data integrity, and loss of customer trust due to security incidents.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might intercept unencrypted traffic between AWS Step Functions and another AWS service, enabling them to access, manipulate, or redirect the unsecured data. Alternatively, attackers might gain unauthorized access by exploiting the insecure network configuration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1043 - Commonly Used Port||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Lack of notifications for security events
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves the potential risk associated with not receiving crucial notifications for security-related events within AWS Step Functions service. Not receiving alerts for these events might leave the system vulnerable to malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could be internal or external attackers, or even automated scripts, which exploit the lack of proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms. This could lead to successful unauthorized activities like data breaches or system disruptions.
Impacts
The major impact includes potential system and data compromise, leading to Integrity, Confidentiality, and Availability (CIA) losses. It may also result in non-compliance with certain regulatory requirements that mandate the use of alerting mechanisms, subsequently leading to legal and financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker, having gained access to AWS Step Functions, carries out malicious activities including data exfiltration or service manipulation. However, due to the lack of proper notifications, these actions go unnoticed until significant damage is done.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description
This refers to a situation where protective measures on data are bypassed, leading to exposure of sensitive information held within AWS Step Functions. This typically occurs when ill-intended individuals or packet sniffers exploit weak security systems to access data that they are not authorized to view. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents for this type of cyber threat could be internal or external adversaries who might engage in activities like spear phishing, password cracking, or exploiting vulnerabilities in security systems. Attack vectors could include malware, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploits that compromise the AWS security environment. Impacts
The resultant impact includes potential loss of private and confidential business customer information, which might cause damage to business reputation, regulatory fines due to non-compliance with data protection laws, or even potential financial loss. 

Example Attack Scenarios
One example of such an attack can be when an attacker compromises an AWS identity with high-level permissions allowing access to AWS Step Functions. This can be achieved through spear phishing or brute force attacks, and once they have this access, they can view or exfiltrate sensitive data, undermining the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.002 - Transmitted Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-1060
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1060: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Automate dependency scanning and updating for security
countermeasure.desc:
Incorporate tools into the deployment pipeline that automatically scan for outdated or vulnerable dependencies and update them to the latest secure versions. Use dependency management tools that integrate with the pipeline to check for known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or packages. Automate the update process to ensure that dependencies are always running the latest secure versions and reduce the risk of exposure to known security flaws.

References:

  • OWASP Dependency-Check

countermeasure.name: Implement RBAC to enforce strict access permissions for the deployment pipeline
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to enforce strict access permissions and ensure that only authorized users can access the deployment pipeline. Define and assign roles based on the principle of least privilege, granting users and systems the minimum level of access necessary to perform their tasks. Regularly review and update role assignments to ensure that only appropriate personnel have access to sensitive pipeline operations, including private signature key management.

References:

  • Cloud IAM Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Log all pipeline actions for traceability and incident response
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all actions performed within the deployment pipeline are thoroughly logged to provide comprehensive traceability of activities involving private signature keys. These logs should capture events such as key access, modifications, deployments, and any security-related operations. Integrate logging with monitoring and alerting systems to facilitate real-time detection of potential incidents, enabling prompt response and investigation. Regularly audit the logs to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify unusual or unauthorized actions.

References:

  • CI/CD Pipeline Security Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Store artifacts in secure, encrypted locations with restricted access
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all deployment artifacts, including private signature keys, configuration files, and other sensitive data, are stored in secure, encrypted locations. Use encryption both at rest and in transit to protect these artifacts from unauthorized access. Implement strict access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel or systems have access to the artifacts, and enforce monitoring to detect any unauthorized attempts to access them.

References:

  • Best Practices for Securing Artifacts in CI/CD

countermeasure.name: Use secrets management tools for secure sensitive information management
countermeasure.desc:
Implement tools such as Azure Key Vault or AWS Secrets Manager to securely store and manage sensitive information, including private signature keys, credentials, API keys, and other secrets. These tools provide centralized management, secure storage, and access control mechanisms, ensuring that sensitive information is protected from unauthorized access. Integrate these tools into your deployment pipeline to automatically fetch and use secrets in a secure manner during runtime.

References:

  • Azure Key Vault Documentation

countermeasure.name: Validate input in pipeline scripts to prevent malicious code execution
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all scripts in the deployment pipeline validate input from any external or untrusted sources to prevent the execution of malicious code. Implement strict input validation mechanisms, such as whitelisting allowed inputs and sanitizing user-provided data, before it is processed by pipeline scripts. This prevents injection attacks, such as command injection or script manipulation, which could lead to system compromise, data leakage, or unauthorized actions within the pipeline.

References:

  • OWASP Input Validation Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Vulnerable dependencies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerable dependencies associated with private signature key management occur when libraries, tools, or frameworks used to handle the keys contain known security vulnerabilities. Exploiting these weaknesses may allow attackers to compromise the key management process, gain unauthorized access to private keys, or tamper with cryptographic operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Attackers: Exploiting known vulnerabilities in cryptographic libraries or key storage tools.
  • Malware: Targeting outdated dependencies to gain control over key management systems.
  • Developers: Failing to update or patch dependencies used in key handling operations.

Impacts

  • Key Compromise: Exploited vulnerabilities can expose private signature keys to unauthorized access.
  • Data Breaches: Tampered cryptographic operations may compromise sensitive data.
  • Loss of Trust: Vulnerable dependencies undermine the integrity of key management systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An outdated cryptographic library with a known vulnerability allows an attacker to extract the private key from memory.
  2. A dependency used in the key management system fails to validate inputs properly, enabling an attacker to inject malicious commands.
  3. A compromised third-party library used for key storage encryption exposes all stored keys to unauthorized parties.
  4. A system administrator fails to update a key management software tool, leaving it vulnerable to an exploit that allows remote access to private keys.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive information
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Exposure of sensitive information occurs when private signature keys or other confidential data are inadvertently made accessible to unauthorized users or systems. This can result from improper storage, inadequate access controls, or vulnerabilities in key management processes, leading to the potential compromise of cryptographic keys and other critical data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting weaknesses in storage or transmission protocols to access sensitive information.
  • Insiders: Unauthorized access to sensitive information due to misconfigured access controls or insufficient monitoring.
  • Malware/Bots: Automated tools scanning for sensitive data in insecure environments, such as unencrypted storage or poorly configured servers.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to private signature keys or sensitive data leads to data theft or manipulation.
  • Compromise of Integrity: Attackers may forge signatures or tamper with data, undermining trust in cryptographic operations.
  • Legal and Compliance Consequences: Failure to protect sensitive information can lead to regulatory violations and legal consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A private signature key is stored in plaintext on a server and accessed by an attacker exploiting an unpatched vulnerability.
  2. Sensitive information, such as encryption keys, is exposed in logs or error messages due to improper sanitization or debugging settings.
  3. An insider with excessive permissions accesses private keys without proper oversight, leading to unauthorized use of the keys.
  4. A private key is transferred over an insecure HTTP connection, intercepted by an attacker during transmission.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient pipeline logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient pipeline logging occurs when the processes used to manage private signature keys or other sensitive data in CI/CD pipelines are not adequately logged. This lack of visibility into pipeline activities can prevent the detection of unauthorized access, key mismanagement, or other security incidents, potentially allowing attackers to exploit vulnerabilities undetected.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Attackers: Exploiting gaps in pipeline visibility to bypass security checks or inject malicious code.
  • Malicious Insiders: Taking advantage of insufficient logging to perform unauthorized actions without leaving traces.
  • Misconfigured Pipelines: Failing to capture and store critical logs related to key usage or sensitive operations.

Impacts

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Security breaches or unauthorized actions in the pipeline go unnoticed, potentially compromising private signature keys.
  • Delayed Incident Response: Without proper logs, identifying and responding to attacks or misconfigurations is slower.
  • Loss of Accountability: Lack of proper logging makes it difficult to attribute actions and enforce accountability for security violations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a private key in the pipeline but no logs are available to track the malicious activity or identify the breach.
  2. A misconfigured pipeline pushes sensitive data without encryption, and the lack of logging makes it difficult to detect or investigate the issue.
  3. A malicious insider alters the pipeline to expose keys or other confidential data, and the insufficient logging prevents the detection of the activity until its too late.
  4. A failed pipeline step that involves private key usage does not generate an appropriate log, leaving the failure undetected and unaddressed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure artifact storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure artifact storage occurs when sensitive data, such as private signature keys or application artifacts, are stored in an unprotected or poorly configured repository. This can lead to unauthorized access, modification, or exfiltration of sensitive information, potentially compromising the integrity and security of the application or system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities in insecure artifact storage systems to access or modify stored artifacts.
  • Malicious Insiders: Exploiting inadequate access controls or weak authentication mechanisms to access sensitive artifacts.
  • Automated Tools: Scanning repositories or storage systems for exposed or misconfigured artifacts containing sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive artifacts, including private keys or configuration files, leading to data theft or misuse.
  • Compromise of Integrity: Attackers may alter or tamper with artifacts, leading to unauthorized changes or signatures.
  • Regulatory Violations: Failure to secure sensitive data in artifact storage may result in non-compliance with data protection regulations like GDPR or PCI-DSS.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A private signature key is stored in a public artifact repository with weak access controls, making it accessible to unauthorized users.
  2. An insider with excessive privileges accesses the artifact storage and steals sensitive data, including encryption keys.
  3. A misconfigured storage bucket allows unauthorized users to retrieve sensitive application artifacts, including API keys and secrets.
  4. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the artifact storage system to inject malicious code into trusted application artifacts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1597 - Search Closed Sources

threat.name: Unvalidated input in pipeline scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unvalidated input in pipeline scripts occurs when data from untrusted sources is directly used in pipeline scripts without proper validation or sanitization. This can lead to malicious code execution, unauthorized system changes, or exploitation of vulnerabilities, as untrusted input may be executed as part of the pipeline, potentially altering the pipeline behavior or compromising the environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Attackers: Injecting malicious inputs into the pipeline through user-provided data or external systems that interact with the pipeline.
  • Malicious Insiders: Using unvalidated input to manipulate pipeline scripts for unauthorized actions, such as stealing credentials or modifying system configurations.
  • Automated Exploits: Attack tools that send malicious inputs to exploit flaws in the pipeline input validation.

Impacts

  • Code Execution Vulnerabilities: Malicious code injected via unvalidated input can be executed in the pipeline, compromising system integrity.
  • Data Breaches: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, such as credentials or private keys, due to improper validation of input in scripts.
  • System Misconfigurations: The pipeline may be altered or misused, causing errors, service outages, or compromised environments.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker injects a malicious payload into a pipeline script through an unvalidated environment variable, executing arbitrary code in the deployment process.
  2. A misconfigured input validation allows a malicious insider to manipulate pipeline inputs, causing the pipeline to deploy unauthorized changes to production environments.
  3. A pipeline script that accepts input from user input fields directly executes a command without sanitization, leading to command injection and system compromise.
  4. Unchecked inputs from an external API integration cause the pipeline to pull a compromised dependency, leading to a supply chain attack.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Unauthorized access to deployment pipeline
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to the deployment pipeline occurs when attackers or unauthorized users gain access to the systems, configurations, or credentials involved in the deployment process. This allows them to alter deployment configurations, inject malicious code, or steal sensitive information, such as private keys or environment variables.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities in the deployment pipeline or system misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access.
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or contractors who abuse their access privileges to disrupt the deployment process or steal sensitive information.
  • Credential Leakage: Exposing access credentials or secrets in code repositories or through misconfigured access controls.

Impacts

  • Compromise of Production Systems: Malicious changes can be deployed to production environments, leading to data breaches, service disruptions, or security exploits.
  • Data Loss: Sensitive information, such as private keys or credentials, may be accessed or exfiltrated by unauthorized users.
  • Reputational Damage: Unauthorized access and breaches in the deployment pipeline may undermine user trust and brand integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to the deployment pipeline by exploiting an unpatched vulnerability in a CI/CD tool, allowing them to modify deployment scripts and inject malicious code.
  2. A malicious insider with access to the pipeline alters the deployment process to leak sensitive credentials or inject backdoors into production systems.
  3. Misconfigured access controls grant external parties read or write access to the deployment pipeline, allowing them to steal private keys or sensitive configurations.
  4. A stolen API key or service account credential from a version control system is used by an attacker to access and modify deployment pipeline configurations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain
